Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Comment: There is an agreement with the logical subject. In the comitative construction the agreement is dual (plural), however a few instances of singular. the verb is always in dual if the subject in a pronoun in dual. If there are two grammatical subjects (such as my mother and my father) in a sentence, the predicate is in the dual. This expresses that the two subjects act together. After quantifiers such as ŋukəgəə ‘many, much’, bǝnsǝ ‘all’ or numerals, the predicate agrees formally with the subject, i.e. it appears in the singular.

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Comment: The predicate agrees in person and number with the subject.

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Comment: Verbs in the objective conjugation agree with the object in number, the ending depends on the number. The verbal marker for object in dual is complex, it contains the dual marker.

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: Yes, but only partially: Only the declination of three grammatical cases (nominative, accusative, genitive) can appear on adjectives. In all other cases, the pre-modifier is in the genitive case.

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: In all locative cases.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Comment: The subject of the temporal clause may be appear in the genitive.

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Comment: With some imperative forms the nominative is used.

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Comment: In the active sentence, the over subject is always expressed with the nominative case.

Name: Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Comment: The suffix -mUNHA shows that a situation takes place reguraly.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Comment: However, the imperfective verbs in the aorist tense refer to the present tense and thus express progressivity.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Comment: The resultative is used to indicate that an action will start immediately.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Comment: All tense markers can appear on the negative auxiliary.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: The dubitative mood may be used to express surprise. There is also an exclamative clitic that has a mirative usage.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Comment: Optative may be used to express wishes or admonition. This mood is, however, rarely attested.

Name: Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Comment: There is necessitive (or debitive mood), but it is only seldom used.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: There is a speculative mood that is used to express speaker's assumptions.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Comment: Reflexive-medial conjugation shows the same person/number marking, e.g. ďeŋhiďi-Ɂi-ti is used for 2DU and 3DU (< ďembiɁsʲi 'to dress').

Name: Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Comment: Passive sentences are formed using a passive suffix or a passive participle.

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Comment: The bare infinitive occurs with motion verbs.

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Comment: Tense and mood markers only appear on verbal categories.

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Comment: If the pivot is expressed by a pronoun, copula is not obligatory.

Name: Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Comment: Conjunctive coordinated clauses are usually juxtaposed without any coordinator. However, there are also some borrowed coordinators. The Russian coordinator is only used at the clause level.

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Comment: The abessive participle.

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Comment: Passive structures can be formed from both transitive and intransitive verbs.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Comment: The abessive participle refers to actions that have not yet occurred.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Comment: However, Helimski (1998) treated the necessitative participle as a future participle.

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Comment: Participles show only partial agreement in case.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Comment: However, there is a separate suffix to indicate professioals, e.g. basu-Ɂsʲi ‘professional hunter’.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: The negative verb must precede the main verb, e.g. ŋanuďətə ŋəmsu ŋuəi-kalʲi-Ɂ ńi-Ɂ mətu-Ɂ [ordinary meat one-CAR-ADV NEGAUX-IMP.2SG cut-CNG] ‘Don’t cut an ordinary meat!’

Name: Are there preverbs?
Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Comment: However, there is a suffix that can be used in the attenuative meaning (i.e. to do sth a bit).

Name: Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Comment: Analytic constructions are used.

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Comment: Plural or dual is rarely used.

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Comment: Historically, there was an endin (-ŋ).

Name: Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Comment: The lative is also used to express the recipient and the beneficiary.

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Comment: Prolative is used to mark direction.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: The suffix has been recently developed from the lative postposition na.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Comment: In addition to a postpositional phrase also the similative marker can be used to express equality.

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Comment: With paired body parts, dual is typically used. In modern texts also plural can be found.

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Comment: The non-pronominal possessor appears in the genitive case, whereas the pronominal possessor occurs in the nominative case (see also UT102).

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Comment: The nominative form is used with pronouns.

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Comment: The possessive suffixes refer to the person and number of the possessor but also the number of the possessed.

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: The referential use of 2sg possessive suffix may occur only when the marked NP occurs in the subject position (see also UT105).

Name: Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: Possessive suffixes can be used in the referential function that is similar to the definite article but it cannot be argued that the language has definite articles.

Name: Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Comment: The distinction is made between humans vs. non-humans. However, in certain cases, 'what' can also be used for a human referent.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Comment: There are no relative pronouns.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Comment: There are no relative pronouns.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Comment: In plural, the number marker and the case suffix are fused.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Comment: However, see Wagner-Nagy (2018: 73): "words that end in long vowels or in vowel sequences trigger stress".

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Comment: It is possible but rare.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Comment: with limitations

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Comment: with limitations

Name: Is there labial vowel harmony?
Comment: with limitations

Name: Are there rising diphthongs?
Comment:
"Nganasan has bimoraic long vowels and vowel sequences, some of which are of a Proto-Samoyedic
origin, as well as two monomoraic “diphthongs”, which Wagner-Nagy renders as [͡ia] and [u͡a], but which could more properly be rendered by monosegmental symbols like [ä] and [å], respectively, especially as they are actually often pronounced as monophthongs" (Janhunen and Gruzdeva 2020).

Name: Are there lowering diphthongs?
Comment: /ia/, /ua/ could be also interpreted as monophthongs

Name: Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Comment: "There would be three unrounded back vowels /a ë ï/, three rounded back vowels /å o u/, three unrounded front vowels /ä e i/, and one lonely high rounded front vowel /ü/ (Janhunen and Gruzdeva 2020)"

Name: Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Comment: also defined as /ɨ/

Name: Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Comment: also defined as /ǝ/

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Comment: /å/ is also defined as /ua/

Name: Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Comment: /ä/ is also defined as /ⁱa/

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Comment: "It is totally unnecessary to distinguish notationally the intervocalic spirant [ð] and the postnasal voiced stop [d], as they represent allophones of a single phoneme that could easily be rendered as /d/ (Janhunen and Gruzdeva 2020)"

Name: Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
